The Hop That Might
The Pigskin Hop is, by tradition, a happily uninhibited affair; everyone valves off vast quantities of
the libidinal steam built up in Homewood's academic
pressure cooker, does homage to the departing football
players and wakes up blearily satisfied on Sunday. If
not a real "Homecoming" it is at least an excuse to
invite a date for the weekend, relax, and relieve the
gray grind before Winter sets in. The function acquired
special significance this year as the only dance to escape
sacrifice to the Cotillion Board's "Big Weekend."
It is thus a major loss when this year's Pigskin
Hop was diluted by its removal to the relatively sedate
surroundings of Levering Hall. The change was, apparently, unavoidable. Blame can be fixed on a malevolent
spirit somewhere in the Gym who may bear the
ephemeral and unsatisfactory designation of McFate.
The reactions to the loss of the dance site were,
however, unfortunate in several respects. The casual
way in which John Morgan was informed that the Gym
could not be used was (see "Correspondence") irresponsible. Surely a development of such significance deserved
prompt and efficient attention. One is led to wonder
what would have happened had a chance encounter not
occurred?
Further, several fraternities have scheduled parties
on Saturday night in response to the change. While
not a surprising reaction, this is hardly in the interests
of the University Community as a whole. Without these
fraternities it will be even more difficult to recreate the
successful mood of past years.
The only thing that can save the Pigskin Hop is
undergraduate "spirit." We have heard that such a
thing now exists at the rim of the Hole. If so, we shall
find out Saturday night.

Disappearing Act
The indefatigable groundskeepers are planting
shrubs around newly completed Barton Hall, a hopeful
sign. Perhaps within a few generations this eyesore will
be obscured by greenery, and with it a blot on our
proud campus removed. In the meantime let us all
pray for rain.

Many of the weekly magazines of the country ran
featured stories this week on the "Rebirth of Hope at
Ole Miss." According to these articles, the Meredith
trial balloon, which appears to be reaching an equilibrium level on the Mississippi campus has burst into a
symbol of light and hope for academic freedom and
educational excellency in the community which once
so perfectly mirrored the novels of its late but distinguished citizen.
The campus at Mississippi has been plagued with
White Citizens Councils ever since the 1954 U. S.
Supreme Court decision declaring segregation on a racial
basis illegal. These councils were literally secret service
groups which recorded speeches and panel discussions.
According to the Saturday Review, even those educators
who voiced "moderate" opinions were profanely criticized and intimidated. The result was that within two
years, one-fourth of the faculty of Ole Miss was advised
to leave the "witch-hunting, thought-control climate."
Presently there is no precedent of dissent on Mississippi's campus, not even on the student newspaper which
has been censored by the White Citizens Councils. However, since the first Meredith incidents, the faculty has
begun to act. Much introspection accompanied by hope
of change has pervaded the University's atmosphere.
Fearful of losing academic accreditation, the administration is no longer acting to suppress dissent in the
faculty quarters.
The dissent ,which is now springing up centers, it
seems, on the le* "good Men" who stuCk by Mississippi
during its recent days of academic slavery. Perhaps in
its improved climate at the University, they can serve
as a rallying point for the fostering of the debate,
rebellion and dissent which is necessary for the freedom
which most American universities cherish and foster.

The Hop That Might
The Pigskin Hop is, by tradition, a happily uninhibited affair; everyone valves off vast quantities of
the libidinal steam built up in Homewood's academic
pressure cooker, does homage to the departing football
players and wakes up blearily satisfied on Sunday. If
not a real "Homecoming" it is at least an excuse to
invite a date for the weekend, relax, and relieve the
gray grind before Winter sets in. The function acquired
special significance this year as the only dance to escape
sacrifice to the Cotillion Board's "Big Weekend."
It is thus a major loss when this year's Pigskin
Hop was diluted by its removal to the relatively sedate
surroundings of Levering Hall. The change was, apparently, unavoidable. Blame can be fixed on a malevolent
spirit somewhere in the Gym who may bear the
ephemeral and unsatisfactory designation of McFate.
The reactions to the loss of the dance site were,
however, unfortunate in several respects. The casual
way in which John Morgan was informed that the Gym
could not be used was (see "Correspondence") irresponsible. Surely a development of such significance deserved
prompt and efficient attention. One is led to wonder
what would have happened had a chance encounter not
occurred?
Further, several fraternities have scheduled parties
on Saturday night in response to the change. While
not a surprising reaction, this is hardly in the interests
of the University Community as a whole. Without these
fraternities it will be even more difficult to recreate the
successful mood of past years.
The only thing that can save the Pigskin Hop is
undergraduate "spirit." We have heard that such a
thing now exists at the rim of the Hole. If so, we shall
find out Saturday night.

Disappearing Act
The indefatigable groundskeepers are planting
shrubs around newly completed Barton Hall, a hopeful
sign. Perhaps within a few generations this eyesore will
be obscured by greenery, and with it a blot on our
proud campus removed. In the meantime let us all
pray for rain.

featured stories this week on the "Rebirth of Hope at
Ole Miss." According to these articles, the Meredith
trial balloon, which appears to be reaching an equilibrium level on the Mississippi campus has burst into a
symbol of light and hope for academic freedom and
educational excellency in the community which once
so perfectly mirrored the novels of its late but distinguished citizen.
The campus at Mississippi has been plagued with
White Citizens Councils ever since the 1954 U. S.
